column1: 18919`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2013construction/03 Mar/20130301_Palmer_01w.pdf`Success`Success`6`6`Not a fillable PDF.`       DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO      CUSTOMER NOTICE INFRASTRUCTURE RENEWAL PROGRAM               March 1
column4: I am providing you with information regarding a  water construction project in your neighborhood. This is part of our approach to renewing our  city’s aging infrastructure. I see this as an opportunity to partner with you our customers. As part  of this partnership
column5: I want to be certain you are well informed about the project. You should  know where to call if you have any questions or concerns.     Our crews will soon be installing 1
column6: 029 feet of 8-inch water main in W. Palmer Street
column7: from N.  Maplewood Avenue to N. Western Avenue. The old pipe dates back to 1887
column8: and needs to be  replaced.    We are coordinating with Alderman Moreno’s office
column9: and he has made clear we are to put great  importance on your convenience and the quality of life in this neighborhood through the whole  term of this project. Good communication is the key.     I have asked my staff to assemble the attached information for you and to monitor the project  closely. We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to minimize inconvenience and noise and to conduct ourselves as good and  thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     If you have questions or comments about the project
column10: please feel free to contact Assistant  Commissioner Tom LaPorte at 312-742-1021 at any time
column11: you may leave a message.     I am also asking you to consider the enclosed information about our MeterSave Program and our  Basement Flooding Partnership (BFP).     Sincerely
column12: Thomas Powers  Commissioner     cc:   Alderman Joe Moreno III                     1st Ward   1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column13: C H I C A G O
column14: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1      Do you wonder what was happening in 1887?  That’s the year the old water main was installed  beneath your street.  Among other things:                                                        Anne Sullivan began teaching 6 year old
column15: blind and deaf Helen Keller.    Oregon became the first state to make Labor Day a holiday.    Britain celebrated the Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria.    Susanna Medora Salter was elected the first U.S. woman mayor (Argonia
column16: Kansas).    The fire escape was patented.    Boris Karloff
column18: was born.            PALMER WATER PROJECT          PROJECT DESCRIPTION     Project:  The Department of Water Management will soon be installing 1
column19: 029 feet of 8-inch  water main in W. Palmer Street
column20: from N. Maplewood Avenue to N. Western Avenue.    Reason:  The old main consists of 6-inch pipe
column21: and we want to expand capacity. Further
column22: the old  pipe dates back to 1887 and needs to be replaced.      Timing:  We will begin installing the new water main shortly
column23: and expect the work to be  completed in late April 2013. Restoration will follow in late May 2013. Dates may change  depending on weather and other factors. If there is any appreciable change
column24: we will notify you.    Traffic: We will allow traffic to flow on Palmer outside of our working hours.  When we are  working in the street
column25: we have to close it to traffic for reasons of safety. You will always be able  to reach your home or business
column26: even if it means putting a metal plate in place.  Outside of  working hours
column27: a lane will be left open for local traffic only.     Parking: We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed
column28: during work hours. We are  agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column29: but will have to insist that cars be moved by the start  of the next workday. We will try to preserve as much parking as we can.     ASSISTANT WATER MANAGEMENT COMMISSIONER TOM LAPORTE   312-742-1021   CONTACT NUMBERS   24-HOUR SERVICE AND INFORMATION LINE      3-1-1   ALDERMAN JOE MORENO III   773-278-0101                                                  FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS               What if there is a problem?  There are always surprises in any construction project.  If you  have any concerns or questions
column30: you can ask our foreman in the street.  You can also call  Assistant Commissioner Tom LaPorte directly at 312-742-1021.  His cell is on the voicemail  message
column31: in case it’s off hours.    Can I park when you’re not working? We have no problem with you parking outside of our  working hours.  We have to insist that cars be out of our way at the start of the workday.     Will this ever end?  Yes.  As a matter of fact
column32: the job is slated to conclude in late April 2013.  Restoration will be completed in late May 2013. We always hesitate to promise specific dates
column33: since we are at the mercy of other factors like weather and emergencies elsewhere in town.    Will you shut my water off? Yes
column34: maybe a couple of times. When we switch over the services  from the old main to the new main
column35: we interrupt service. We give you 24-hour notice when this  is to happen.  In any construction project
column36: there is also a risk that an old pipe will break.  They  can be fragile. This may necessitate an emergency shutdown.  If we do this
column37: we will let you know  what is happening
column38: even though we may be unable to give prior warning.    Why should I be nice about this?  The crew working in the street will work hard to be good  neighbors
column39: and to respect both your convenience and your quality-of-life.  By working together
column40: we can complete this important project as friends working for the improvement of our  community.               DOES YOUR BASEMENT FLOOD?     The Department of Water Management would like to work with you and your neighbors to  reduce the risk of basement flooding.  We are promoting a collective response as the only  strategy—homeowners joining together on a neighborhood basis to work with us on  practical steps (public and private) to protect your property and peace of mind.    Want to learn more?  http://www.cityofchicago.org/watermanagement/bfp   DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO                  What is MeterSave?    MeterSave is a program to encourage Chicago homeowners to voluntarily install meters to  monitor water usage. Meters allow single family and two-flat homeowners to pay for only the  water actually used
column41: encouraging efforts to save water and money while protecting one of our  most precious natural resources.    Water charges in non-metered homes are tied to factors such as building size
column42: lot-size and  number of plumbing fixtures. Metered homes are billed according to actual use. This means that  with minimal effort
column43: participating homeowners could save money on their water bills.                Homeowner Incentives   Non-metered homeowners participating in MeterSave are eligible for the following:    A 7-year guarantee that the home water bill will be no higher than it would have if the meter   had not been installed. Bill will not exceed the assessed rate for that year.     Choice of one of the following (while supplies last):   rain barrel
column44:     water meter monitor (a refrigerator magnet that shows water usage)    outdoor water conservation kit or      And
column45: two of the above incentives if a whole block volunteers!   indoor water conservation kit   Frequently Asked Questions:   How and when do I sign up?   Interested non-metered single family and two-flat homeowners may visit www.metersave.org
column47: or call 312-744-4H2O. Please have your 12-digit account number ready.  Space is  limited based on funding availability and the number of volunteers.     What will it cost to participate?  The City of Chicago Department of Water Management will install a water meter complete with  the automatic meter reading (AMR) technology in your home FREE of charge.    AMR technology allows readings to be transmitted via wireless radio technology to Water  Management vehicles as they drive by
column48: eliminating the need for readings to take place inside the  home.  Bills will be issued bi-monthly and reflect only the actual amount of water used.     Do I have to be current on my water bill?  Yes.  Homeowners must be current on payment plan and water bill to participate in this limited  time offer of a 7-year guarantee.    For payment plan information call 312-744-4H20 (4426).      1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column49: C H I C A G O
column50: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1            When can I have a meter installed?  Online meter installation scheduling is available at www.metersave.org  Otherwise
column51: Water  Management will contact you to schedule a time for meter installation.      Small changes made by Chicagoans can have a tremendous impact on the sustainability of  our water supply
column52: such as:     Turn off the faucet while brushing your teeth or shaving.  This can save over 500 gallons  per month per person.    Install high-efficiency
column53: low-flow toilets.  Toilets alone consume 26% of household water  consumption.  A leaky toilet wastes 200 gallons of water per day.    Install high-efficiency washing machines. This can save energy and water consumption.    Fill the sink with dishwater instead of washing dishes with an open tap.  This saves 25  gallons per wash.    If you own a dishwasher
column54: wait until you have a full load to run it.  Dishwashers typically  use half the energy
column56: and less soap than washing dishes in the sink.    Garden with plants that are native to Chicago.  This can reduce outdoor water use by 20- 50%.    Use rain barrels to capture rainwater for watering lawns and gardens.    Use a timer or a rain sensor to monitor lawn irrigation: Sprinkler systems use thousands  of gallons of water per cycle.  Installing a timer or rain sensor will save money and water by  preventing needless watering.         WATER   Our Most Precious Resource   Lake Michigan has lost almost 32 trillion gallons of water--the equivalent of over 45 million  Olympic-sized swimming pools of water-- over the past decade. Our region could face severe  water shortages by 2050 if we fail to take decisive action.     More than half of water consumption in Chicago occurs within homes.   Over 5.4 million people-- 44% of the population of the State of Illinois
column57: depend on the Chicago  Department of Water Management to provide a reliable supply of drinking water from Lake  Michigan.     Volunteer for a meter today to save water and money!           Please go to www.metersave.org     By phone call 3-1-1

LOCATIONS WHERE PERMITTED:   1. Display of fireworks in public parks or other public open spaces Section 15-20-240 of  the Municipal Code of Chicago.   2. Display of fireworks on privately owned property as required in Section 15-4-550 of  the Municipal Code of Chicago.   B. DISPLAY PROHIBITED   No fireworks display shall be permitted between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00  a.m.                                                       II    PERMIT PROCEDURE   A.    Submit to the Bureau of Fire Prevention the Following:   1.    2.    3.    4.    5.   Proof of compliance with all provisions of the Illinois Pyrotechnic   Operators Licensing Act
column2: as amended; proof of compliance with Illinois  Fireworks Use Act
column4: per Section 15-4-550 of the Chicago  Municipal Code. (Web site: state.il.us/osfm)   Explosive license as required by Section 15-4-310 of the Chicago  Municipal Code. New applicants are to apply to the Director of Business  Affairs and Licensing. (Web site: cityofchicago.org)   Certificate of Fitness for the individual(s) involved with the display as per  Section 15-4-340 of the Chicago Municipal Code. New applicants are to  apply to the Bureau of Fire Prevention. A fee of $50.00 per person is  required.   A letter of consent from the owner of the property allowing the fireworks  display.    A letter of consent from the alderman in whose ward the fireworks  display will take place.   6.    7.   A certificate of insurance in the amount not less than $1
column6: 000 issued  by an insurer authorized to insure risks in Illinois. The City of Chicago and  its officers and employees shall be named as additional insured. This  Certificate of Insurance shall be approved by the Department of Finance
column7: Risk Management Division of the City of Chicago.   A plan consistent with the principles set forth in NFPA 1123
column8: to the  Deputy Fire Commissioner of the Bureau of Fire Prevention. This plan  shall include the dimensions of the discharge site
column11: fall out area and associated separation distances.   B.    Schedule an on-site inspection
column12: which shall be conducted by the Deputy Fire  Commissioner of the Bureau of Fire Prevention or his designee
column13: to obtain approval or  modifications of the proposed site and display consistent with the principals set forth in  NFPA 1123.   * In no case shall any display of fireworks be conducted unless the site meets the safety  standards set forth by the Fire Department.   Proof of a liquor license is required if the proposed location for the display is to take  place on the premises that sell alcoholic beverages for consumption.   Permit application will be reviewed providing all the above information has  been  submitted along with a valid payment receipt attached to the POS invoice. Download  the POS invoice. Complete the POS invoice
column14: then remit payment of $70.00 per display at  any City of Chicago payment site and obtain a valid payment receipt attached to the POS  invoice. To locate City of Chicago payment locations go  to: http://www.cityofchicago.org/finance.   C.    D.

column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s “Building a New Chicago” infrastructure  improvement program
column5: I would like to provide you with  information about an upcoming sewer main construction project in your neighborhood.     In August
column6: the Department of Water Management’s crews will begin work to install a new  sewer main in N. Hamlin Avenue (Irving Park-Elston). The old sewer dates back to 1901  and needs to be replaced.     During construction
column7: we will require a partial closure of Irving Park at Hamlin for a few  days. Detour routes will be posted in advance. Otherwise
column8: when we are working in the  street
column9: we may close it to traffic for safety reasons
column10: but you will always be able to reach your  home or business.  Outside of working hours
column11: a travel lane will be left open for local traffic  only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am- 4pm).  We are agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column12: but cars will need to be moved  by the start of the next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column13: and  conducting ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on  your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column14: you can either ask the construction foreman  during the project
column15: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour Service and Information Line:  311    45th Ward Office: 773-286-4545    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635   Lastly
column16: if you don’t already have one
column17: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter  in your home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free  program
column18: go to www.metersave.org.     Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important  infrastructure improvement project.          Sincerely

column1: 21327`https://www.cityofchicago.org/dam/city/depts/bacp/publicvehicleinfo/publicvehicle/amededpublicchauffeurrulesandregulations.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`   City of Chicago                                Department of Business Affairs and    Consumer Protection    PUBLIC VEHICLE INDUSTRY NOTICE   December 14
column2: 2012               Notice No. 12-061   AMENDED    PUBLIC CHAUFFEUR RULES AND REGULATIONS     The Amended Public Chauffeur Rules and Regulations
column3: pursuant to MCC  Chapters 2-25 and 9-104 are now available online at the Department of  Business Affairs and Consumer Protection (BACP) Web site:   www.cityofchicago.org/bacp.     The public chauffeur rules now include a “CH” prefix to each rule and were  amended after notice and comment as follows:   1.  Olive Harvey College
column5: is now authorized to  administer public chauffeur training courses and licensing exams for  both taxicab and limo driver applicants.   2.  BACP will no longer administer the licensing exams for taxicab and   limo drivers.   3.  Public chauffeurs may renew their licenses up to 45 days before their   licenses expire.  They no longer need to wait to renew in their birth  month.   4.  Starting immediately
column6: Public chauffeur licensees will be issued with   expiration dates based on the licensee’s birth date – thus licenses will  expire on specific dates throughout the month of birth as Illinois  State driver licenses do.   5.  Public chauffeur licensees will have up to 6 months after expiration of  their license to renew their expired license without retaking the exam  or licensing course.     For questions or to join the BACP mailing list to receive industry notices and other department  news
column7: send an email to BACPPV@cityofchicago.org.  Rules and Regulations governing City of  Chicago licensed public vehicles and public chauffeurs are available at  www.cityofchicago.org/bacp. The Municipal Code of Chicago is available at www.amlegal.com.   Public Vehicle Operations Division ● 2350 W. Ogden

column1: 13648`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/FEMAcleanUp.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`" FEMA   After The Flood: Clean Up And Stay Safe     Release Date: April 2
column2: 2009  Release Number: 3304-002   » More Information on Minnesota Severe Storms and Flooding    ST. PAUL
column3: Minn. -- Individuals affected by the flooding that began on March 16
column5: are urged to begin  cleaning up their homes and personal property as soon as possible. Officials from Minnesota’s Homeland  Security Emergency Management (HSEM) and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA)  emphasize that it is not necessary to wait for an inspection before beginning this process.   ""We encourage individuals affected by the disaster to remain cautious and return home only when it is safe to  do so
column6: said Federal Coordinating Officer Mike Smith. ""Property owners should document all losses and  damages by taking photos first
column8: and then begin immediately removing all flood damaged  personal property.""   Before making permanent repairs to your home-such as drywall
column10: electrical systems or  plumbing-make sure you get the proper permits from your local community or county permitting officials. This  is especially important for those living in a Special Flood Hazard Area to ensure compliance with local  floodplain management requirements.   ""Our main concern is the health and safety of Minnesotans as they begin the clean-up process
column11: said State  Coordinating Officer Kris Eide. ""It is important for homeowners to get accurate information from state and  local officials in order to protect themselves and their loved ones.""   The following precautions are suggestions that residents in flooded areas may want to implement:     Confirm the water supply is safe to drink. Listen for news reports to learn whether the community’s  water supply has been contaminated by the floodwaters. Remember to carry bottled drinking water and  discard any food products that may have come in contact with floodwater.     Wear protective clothing. Protect yourself during cleanup by wearing boots
column12: gloves and masks. Clean     Ventilate your home. Open all doors and windows to allow air to circulate and dry out your home.     Service damaged septic tanks
column14: pit and leaching systems as soon as possible. Damaged   and disinfect everything floodwater contacted.   Dehumidify as soon as possible after a flood.   sewage systems are serious health hazards.     Make a list of lost or damaged items. Be sure to include their age and value
column16: have   receipts for those items available.     Prevent mold growth. Wash all surface areas in the house that came in contact with floodwater.   Disinfect and wipe surfaces dry with paper towels to minimize bacterial contamination.  Isolate any moldy objects. Seal moldy trash in plastic bags and remove them immediately. Objects you  can save should be dried or frozen as soon as possible. Freezing inactivates mold.      For more tips on cleaning up and keeping your family safe
column18: www.minnesotarecovers.org  or the CDC’s flood website at www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/floods/.   FEMA coordinates the Federal government's role in preparing for
column22: and recovering from all domestic disasters
column24: including acts of    safe.   Last Modified: Thursday

column1: 18021`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2017construction/jan_2017/20170118_Houston_83rd_07w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1701141    January 18
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By late January 2017
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and Benchmark Construction  Company crews will begin the work to install 1
column7: 369 feet of new 8-inch water main in S. Houston  Avenue
column8: from E. 82nd Street to E. 83rd Place
column10: from S. Commercial Avenue to S. Bond  Avenue and E. 83rd Street
column11: from S. Commercial Avenue to S. Houston Avenue. The old water main  dates back to 1890
column12: and needs to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column13: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column14: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column15: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column16: to the installation of new  pipes
column17: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column18: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column19: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column20: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column21: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column22: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column23: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column24: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  7th Ward Office: 773-731-7777  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column25: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column26: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column27: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column28: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column30: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column32: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column33: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column34: or if you would like your water  tested
column35: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column36: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column37: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column38: if you don’t already have one
column39: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column40: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.     Sincerely
